The '''Church Educational System (CES) Honor Code''' is a set of standards by which students and faculty attending a school owned and operated by [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church) are required to live. The most widely known university that is part of the [[Church Educational System]] (CES) that has adopted the honor code is [[Brigham Young University]] (BYU), located in [[Provo, Utah]]. The standards are largely derived from codes of conduct of the LDS Church, and were not put into written form until the 1940s. Since then, they have undergone several changes. The CES Honor Code also applies for students attending BYU's sister schools [[Brigham Young University–Idaho]], [[Brigham Young University–Hawaii]], and [[LDS Business College]].
==History of the Honor Code at BYU== [[File:BYU_Honor_Code_Office.png|thumb|right|BYU Honor Code office entrance]] Every year BYU has an "Honor Week" dedicated to celebrating the legacy of the Honor Code and to remind students of the importance of following it.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cable|first1=Jessica|title=BYU celebrates student standards through annual Honor Week|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2017/02/13/byu-celebrates-student-standards-through-annual-honor-week/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=13 Feb 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Da Silva|first1=Carla|title=Preparations being made for Honor Week activities|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2013/02/14/preparations-being-made-for-honor-week-activities-online/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=14 Feb 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Ternieden|first1=John|title=Honor Code celebrated in Student Honor Week|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2012/01/25/honor-code-byu-celebration/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=25 Jan 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Tillotson|first1=Carolina|title=Honor Week offers prizes and a chance to remember|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2005/11/29/honor-week-offers-prizes-and-a-chance-to-remember/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=29 Nov 2005}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Anderson|first1=Elisa|title=Honor week finds missionaries on campus|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2003/04/07/honor-week-finds-missionaries-on-campus/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=7 April 2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McCann|first1=Summer|title="Honor Week" reminds students of commitments|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2001/11/27/honor-week-reminds-students-of-commitments/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=27 Nov 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Fife|first1=Erin|title=Honor Week to be celebrated through performance|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2001/04/02/honor-week-to-be-celebrated-through-performance/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=2 Apr 2001}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Orozco|first1=Jessica|title=Honor Week to honor Christmas|url=http://universe.byu.edu/1999/11/28/honor-week-to-honor-christmas/|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=28 Nov 1999}}</ref> Early forms of the CES Honor Code are found as far back as the days of the Brigham Young Academy (1875–1903).<ref name="history">{{cite web| title =Brigham Young High School History: 1869 to 1903 - The Founding Years | publisher =Brigham Young High School| url =http://abc.eznettools.net/D300015/X329586/History/HistoryDecades/From1869to1903.html| accessdate = August 19, 2007 }}</ref><ref name="byhigh">{{cite web| title =From 1903 to 1920 ~ A High School Within a University| work =Brigham Young High School History| publisher =Brigham Young High School| year= 2007| url =http://www.byhigh.org/History/HistoryDecades/From1903to1920.html| accessdate = August 20, 2007 }}</ref> Early school president, [[Karl G. Maeser]]. Maeser created the "Domestic Organization", which was a group of teachers who would visit students at their homes to see that they were following the school's moral rules. In the 1901 school catalog this guide of conduct included a prohibition on "strong drink and tobacco", "profanity and obscenity", attending parties not under the control of "responsible persons", "keeping late hours, having improper associates, and visiting places of questionable repute".<ref>{{cite book|title=1901-1902 Catalogue (sic)|date=1901|publisher=Brigham Young Academy|location=Provo, Utah|pages=10–11|url=https://archive.org/stream/cataloguesannoun19011902brig#page/10/mode/2up}}</ref> Maeser also, however, relied largely on individual student's [[honor]] and honesty in keeping the rules, intending faculty visits as times of counsel rather than espionage. After [[George H. Brimhall]] served as president, enforcement became somewhat more lax (there were no more faculty visits), but adherence to the same basic principles were encouraged. From 1910 to 1960 the annual student catalog would only contain a few brief sentences on student conduct and discipline, often mentioning the prohibition of tobacco, "improper associates", and "visiting places of questionable repute",<ref>{{cite book|title=1960-1961 Annual Catalog|date=Fall 1960|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, Utah|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogofcourses19601961brig#page/80/mode/2up}}</ref> though the 1930s and 40s saw increased standards regarding rules related to student housing and the dress code. Women were allowed to wear slacks only on Saturdays, and men wore uniforms for a short time.<ref name=BYUhouse3>{{cite book |last1= Bergera |first1= Gary James |last2= Priddis |first2= Ronald |year= 1985 |chapter= Chapter 3: Standards & the Honor Code |chapter-url= http://signaturebookslibrary.org/?p=13895 |title= Brigham Young University: A House of Faith |place= Salt Lake City |publisher= [[Signature Books]] |isbn= 0-941214-34-6 |oclc= 12963965 }}</ref>
In 1949 students drafted the first Honor Code enforced by an Honor Council of students and administrators, and was used mainly for cases of cheating and [[academic dishonesty]].<ref name="ReferenceA">{{cite journal|last1=Piper|first1=Matthew|title=The history of BYU’s Honor Code: From ‘an institution practically without rules’ to one that exterminates ‘beetles, beatniks or buzzards,’ and beyond|journal=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=29 Oct 2016|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/3854493-155/the-history-of-byus-honor-code|accessdate=22 November 2016}}</ref> The Student Honor Council, created around 1949, oversaw case violations. This council met with enough success among students in alleviating cheating that in 1957 BYU president [[Ernest L. Wilkinson]] suggested the Honor Code expand to include other school standards. This led to an expansion during the 1960s which created the bulk of what the Honor Code represents today: rules regarding chastity, dress, grooming, drugs, and alcohol.<ref name=BYUhouse3 /> Instead of a short paragraph on university standards,<ref>{{cite book|title=Annual Catalog Issue 1966-1968|date=Fall 1966|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, Utah|page=41|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogofcourses19661968brig#page/41/mode/2up}}</ref> the undergraduate catalog began printing a more detailed set of Honor Code policies in 1968, including a clause requiring students to act when observing any violation and a list of banned drugs ("amphetamines, barbiturates, hallucinogenic drugs, psychedelic drugs, and narcotics").<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=L. Howard|title=BYU Annual Catalog Issue 1968-1970|date=Fall 1968|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, Utah|pages=39–40|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogofcourses19681970brig#page/38/mode/2up}}</ref> This change came because the administration completely took over the previously student run honor code and disbanded the student senate and student honor code committee.<ref name="A history of the BYU Honor Code">{{cite news|last1=Bitterman|first1=Sara|title=A history of the BYU Honor Code|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2014/04/08/a-history-of-the-byu-honor-code/|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=8 April 2014}}</ref> The honor code was expanded in the 1970 catalog with a requirement to adhere to the "standards of dress" and the addition of marijuana and LSD to the list of banned drugs.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=L. Howard|title=BYU Annual Catalog Issue 1970-1972|date=Fall 1970|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, Utah|pages=37–38|url=https://archive.org/stream/catalogofcourses19701972brig#page/36/mode/2up}}</ref>
In the 1960s, several rules regarding longer hairstyles in men were introduced after long hair on men became associated with the radical movements then springing up on college campuses around the country. However, long hair and beards were not completely against the rules until the mid-1970s<ref name="A history of the BYU Honor Code"/> with the 1978 annual catalog being the first edition to contain any detailed dress and grooming standards code.<ref>{{cite book|title=1978-1979 General Catalog of Courses|date=January 1978|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, Utah|url=https://archive.org/stream/generalcatalog19781979brig#page/6/mode/2up}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceA"/> The 1960s also saw changes in rules regarding women's dress, as LDS Church leaders made statements against low-cut dresses and short skirts. By this time, women were allowed to wear slacks and pant-suits, but jeans were not allowed until 1981.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Randle|first1=Jenna|title=70s BYU student undressed to take a test|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2014/11/04/26-years-later-the-story-of-anita-welch1/|agency=Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=4 Nov 2014}}</ref>
==Standards== The CES Honor Code governs not only academic behavior but also everyday conduct on or off campus as well as dress and grooming standards of students and faculty, with the aim of providing an atmosphere consistent with LDS principles.<ref>{{citation |url=http://registrar.byu.edu/catalog/2014-2015ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |title=Church Educational System Honor Code |work=2014-2015 Undergraduate Catalog |publisher=Brigham Young University |access-date=2015-07-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141125225815/http://registrar.byu.edu/catalog/2014-2015ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |archive-date=2014-11-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The Honor Code requires:
*Abstinence from [[recreational drug|illicit drugs]], [[alcoholic beverage|alcohol]], [[tobacco]], [[coffee]], and [[tea]] (substances forbidden by the LDS [[Word of Wisdom]]) *Honesty *Encouraging others in their commitment to keep the Honor Code *Living a [[Law of chastity|chaste]] and virtuous life: **Appropriate gender-specific behavior (no [[sexual harassment]]) **No involvement with [[Pornography|pornographic]] or indecent material **No inappropriate sexual activity (no [[premarital sex|premarital]] or [[extramarital sex]]) **No homosexual behavior *Obedience to the law *Maintaining an ecclesiastical endorsement from a leader of the local congregation or the nondenominational BYU chaplain<ref name="policy.byu.edu">{{cite web|title=Church Educational System Honor Code|url=https://policy.byu.edu/view/index.php?p=26&s=s1167|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=12 March 2017}}</ref> *Respect for others *Clean language (no [[profanity]]) *Following the "Residential Living Standards" (visiting hours for members of the opposite sex) *Dress and Grooming Standards: Abiding by the guidelines for dress, grooming, and housing. [[Skirt]]s must reach to the [[knee]] and shirts may not be sleeveless. Form fitting, strapless and revealing clothing is not appropriate. Male students may not wear [[beard]]s or [[goatee]]s, hair length must be above the ears, and sideburns must not extend below the ear lobe. *Students are prohibited from having guns on campus.<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2006/02/28/concealed-weapons-prohibited-at-byu/ |title= Concealed Weapons Prohibited at BYU |first= David |last= Johnson |date= February 28, 2006 |newspaper= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref>
Specific additional restrictions on appearance have been mentioned including those deemed as "extreme fashion" including a ban on shaved heads for women, blue hair, long nails or eyeshadow for men, and any piercings besides a single pair for women.<ref name="Honor Code Faculty Information">{{cite web|title=Honor Code Faculty Information|url=http://facultycenter.byu.edu/honor-code-faculty-information|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref>
==Policies on homosexuality== {{seealso|Brigham Young University LGBT history|Homosexuality and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints}}
===Ban on gay students=== Before the 1960s there was little explicit mention of homosexuality by BYU administration, but by 1962 a ban on homosexual students was enacted. On 12 September 1962 Apostles [[Spencer W. Kimball]] and [[Mark E. Peterson]] and BYU President [[Ernest L. Wilkinson]] agreed on a university policy that "no one will be admitted as a student ... whom we have convincing evidence is a homosexual". They agreed to share information about individuals cases of homosexual members between general church administration and BYU administration.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Anderson|first1=Seth|title=Timeline of Mormon Thinking About Homosexuality|url=http://www.nomorestrangers.org/timeline-of-mormon-thinking-about-homosexuality/|website=NoMoreStrangers.org|publisher=No More Strangers: LGBT Mormon Forum|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Ernest L.|title=BYU Diary|date=12 September 1962|publisher=Brigham Young University|location=BYU Library Special Collections UA 1000 Box 101 Folder 1|url=http://files.lib.byu.edu/ead/XML/UA1000.xml|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> This policy was reiterated in Wilkinson's address to BYU in 1965 when he stated "we [do not] intend to admit to this campus any homosexuals. ... [I]f any of you have this tendency, ... may I suggest you leave the University immediately .... We do not want others on this campus to be contaminated by your presence."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Ernest|title=Make Honor Your Standard|date=23 Sep 1965|publisher=Brigham Young University|page=8}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Ernest|title=Make Honor Your Standard|journal=Deseret News: Church News|date=13 Nov 1965|page=11}}</ref> The 1967 version of the Honor code stated that "homosexuality will not be tolerated" along with not approving "any form of artificial birth control".<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilkinon|first1=Ernest L.|title=Presidential Files, Memorandum: Conference Held with First Presidency|date=18 August 1967|publisher=BYU|location=Provo, UT, BYU HBLL Special Collections UA 1000 Box 271 Folder 22|page=2|url=http://files.lib.byu.edu/ead/XML/UA1000.xml|accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref>
The ban on any homosexually oriented students was softened a decade later by Wilkinson's successor [[Dallin H. Oaks]] in a 19 April 1973 Board of Trustees meeting. There it was decided BYU would allow students who had "repented of" homosexual acts and "forsaken" them for a "lengthy period of time". Additionally they would allow students "guilty of irregular sexual behavior" (not including fornication or adultery equivalents) who were "repentant" and "showed evidence" that the act(s) would "not be repeated" while still banning overt and active homosexuals.<ref name="BYU Board Meeting Minutes">{{cite book|title=BYU Board Meeting Minutes|date=19 April 1973|publisher=BYU|location=BYU Library Special Collections|pages=6–7|url=http://files.lib.byu.edu/ead/XML/UA1085.xml}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=O'Donovan|first1=Connell|title=Private Pain, Public Purges: A History of Homosexuality at Brigham Young University|url=http://exmormon.org/d6/drupal/byuhis|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref>
===Shock therapy=== According to the Standards Office director from 1971 to 1981, all homosexual BYU students who were reported to the Standards Office (now called the Honor Code Office) were either expelled, or, for "less serious" offenses, were required to undergo therapy in order to remain at the university; in "special cases" this treatment included "electroshock and vomiting aversion therapies".<ref name="BYU Board Meeting Minutes"/><ref name="Signature Books">{{cite book|last1=Corcoran|first1=Brent|last2=O'Donovan|first2=Rocky|title=Multiply and Replenish: Mormon Essays on Sex and Family|date=1994|publisher=Signature Books|location=Salt Lake City, Utah|isbn=1560850507|page=155|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/the-abominable-and-detestable-crime-against-nature/|accessdate=29 November 2016}}</ref> This [[Homosexuality and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints#Aversion therapy at BYU|program]] of aversion therapy—which spanned from the late 1950s until at least the late 1970s—was dedicated to "curing" male homosexual students reported by bishops and BYU administrators through administering electrical shocks or vomit inducing drugs while showing "nude" pictures of men to the patient in an attempt to associate pain with homosexual visual stimulation.<ref name=mormon-gay-cures>{{citation |url= http://abcnews.go.com/Health/mormon-gay-cures-reparative-therapies-shock-today/story?id=13240700&singlePage=true |title= Mormon 'Gay Cure' Study Used Electric Shocks Against Homosexual Feelings |work= [[Good Morning America]] |publisher= [[ABC News]] |first= Susan Donaldson |last= James |date= March 30, 2011 |accessdate= July 2, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Quinn|first1=D. Michael|title=Same-Sex Dynamics among Ninceteenth-Century Americans|date=1996|publisher=University of Illinois Press|isbn=978-0252022050|pages=377, 379}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Waterman|first1=Bryan|last2=Kagel|first2=Brian|title=The Lord’s University: Freedom and Authority at BYU|date=1998|publisher=Signature books|isbn=1-56085-117-1|page=162|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/the-lords-university-04/|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="BYU Electroshock Thesis">{{cite book|last1=McBride|first1=Ford|title=Effects of Visual Stimuli in Electric Aversion Therapy|date=Aug 1976|publisher=BYU Department of Psychology|location=Provo, UT, USA|page=43|url=https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B1u3K43P-3JoY2Q5NDY3ZjYtNWUyMi00YWJiLWFhM2EtYTE4MjViNWVjOGEz/view?layout=list&ddrp=1&num=50&sort=name&pli=1#|accessdate=23 October 2016}}</ref><ref name="one">{{Citation|url=http://www.affirmation.org/therapy/with_all_thy_getting.shtml |publisher=Affirmation: Gay & Lesbian Mormons |title=With All Thy Getting, Get Understanding |first=Don D. |last=Harryman |accessdate=August 19, 2011 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131021171348/http://www.affirmation.org/therapy/with_all_thy_getting.shtml |archivedate=October 21, 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{citation |url= http://www.mercurynews.com/faith/ci_17631272?source=pkg |title= Can gays be 'cured'? Controversial practice attempts just that |first= Michelle |last= Beaver |date= March 20, 2011 |newspaper= [[San Jose Mercury News]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Collins|first1=Mark|title=Theater: '14' examines violent therapy for gay Mormons in the 1970s|journal=Daily Camera|date=16 October 2011|url=http://www.dailycamera.com/theater-dance/ci_19105788|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref><ref name="Legacies: BYU Conversion Therapy">{{cite web|last1=Weakland|first1=Sean|title=Legacies|url=http://brbl-dl.library.yale.edu/vufind/Record/4192006|website=Yale University Library|accessdate=29 September 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Cowan|first1=Reed|title=8: The Mormon Proposition|publisher=David v. Goliath Films|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1484522/|ref=8: The Mormon Proposition Documentary}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|date=August 12, 2006|title=Question #27629|work=The 100 Hour Board|publisher=BYU|url=http://theboard.byu.edu/questions/27629/|accessdate=August 26, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Bergera|first1=James|last2=Priddis|first2=Ronald|title=Brigham Young University: A House of Faith|date=1985|publisher=Signature Books|isbn=0941214346|page=82|url=http://signaturebookslibrary.org/integrating-religion-academics/|accessdate=21 November 2016}}</ref>
===Ban on advocacy and coming out=== [[File:Gay_BYU_Logo_Parody.png|175px|thumb|right|A gay pride parody of the "Y" logo]] In the late 1990s a reference to homosexual conduct was added to the code, and in 2001 Associate Dean of Students Lane Fischer over the BYU Honor Code Office stated that it was inappropriate for a BYU student to advocate for the [homosexual] lifestyle by publishing material or participating in public demonstrations as well as advertising ones same-sex preference in any public way. He also required homosexual students facing discipline to refrain from same-sex "dating, holding hands, kissing, romantic touching, showering, clubbing, ets., as well as regular association with homosexual men."<ref name="BYU Brass Suspend Two Gays">{{cite news|last1=Stewart|first1=Kirsten|title=BYU Brass Suspend Two Gays|agency=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=29 March 2001}}</ref>
===Current policies=== In 2007, BYU changed the honor code to read that stating one's sexual orientation was not an honor code issue while removing the phrase that "any behaviors that indicate homosexual conduct, including those not sexual in nature, are inappropriate and violate the Honor Code." The change also clarified the policy on advocacy of LGBTQ rights or romantic relationships.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Lyon|first1=Julia|title=BYU changes honor code text about gay students|url=http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/news/ci_5684555|accessdate=15 January 2017|agency=Salt Lake Tribune|date=17 April 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Walch|first1=Tad|title=BYU clarifies Honor Code about gay orientation|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/660212820/-BYU-clarifies-Honor-Code-about-gay-orientation.html|accessdate=15 January 2017|agency=Deseret News|publisher=LDS Church|date=18 April 2007}}</ref> Several students, including gay and lesbian students, thought that the previous wording was confusing and unclear. While both homosexuals and heterosexuals must abide by the church's [[law of chastity]] (i.e. no sexual relations outside of marriage, no crude language, and no pornography),<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2007/04/17/byu-clarifies-honor-code/ |title= BYU Clarifies Honor Code |first= Jenna |last= Morrison |date= April 17, 2007 |newspaper= [[The Universe (BYU)|The Universe]] |publisher= BYU}}</ref> the Honor Code additionally prohibits all forms of physical intimacy that give expression to homosexual feelings (i.e. dating, kissing). There is no similar restriction against expressing heterosexual feelings.<ref>{{citation|url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php|title=Church Educational System Honor Code|work=2009-2010 Undergraduate Catalog|publisher=BYU|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903210257/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php|archivedate=2011-09-03|df=}}</ref> The first explicit mention of homosexuality in the language of the school's code of conduct available to students was not noted until the Fall of 2009.<ref>{{cite web|title=2008 Church Educational System Honor Code |url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2008-2009ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |website=byu.edu |publisher=BYU |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140608222002/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2008-2009ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |archivedate=2014-06-08 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Church Educational System Honor Code |url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |website=byu.edu |publisher=BYU |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903210257/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |archivedate=2011-09-03 |df= }}</ref> Both this version and the 2010 versions contained a clause banning homosexual advocacy defined as "seeking to influence others to engage in homosexual behavior or promoting homosexual relations as being morally acceptable."<ref>{{cite web|title=2009 Church Educational System Honor Code |url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |website=byu.edu |publisher=BYU |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903210257/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |archivedate=2011-09-03 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2010 Church Educational System Honor Code |url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2010-2011ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |website=byu.edu |publisher=BYU |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100828063509/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2010-2011ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |archivedate=2010-08-28 |df= }}</ref> In early 2011, BYU quietly removed the clause prohibiting advocacy.<ref>{{citation |url= http://gaysaltlake.com/news/2011/02/02/byu-removes-pro-gay-advocacy-from-its-honor-code/ |title= BYU removes pro-gay advocacy from its honor code |date= February 2, 2011 |newspaper= [[QSaltLake]] |publisher= QSaltLake}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=2010 Church Educational System Honor Code |url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2010-2011ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |website=byu.edu |publisher=BYU |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110414163048/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2010-2011ucat/GeneralInfo/HonorCode.php |archivedate=2011-04-14 |df= }}</ref>
==Enforcement== Honor code policies and principles are promoted by [[Brigham Young University Student Service Association|BYUSA]], the campus student association, and the Honor Code Office. The office handles all accusations and violations, and works in conjunction with [[Bishop (Latter Day Saints)|bishops]] of BYU [[Ward (LDS Church)|wards]]. If the student's bishop is thought to be able to corroborate the alleged infraction, the accused student may be required to sign a legal form waiving his or her rights to ecclesiastical privacy, which allows the school direct access to the bishop and any content discussed on the said topic, or others which may have been in violation of the Honor Code, but not yet reported. Not all students at the school are familiar with LDS standards, so students who break the code for the first time are usually only contacted by mail as a warning and clarification of standards. Later violations may cause the student to be called into the office to speak with an Honor Code officer. Severe and continued violations can merit expulsion.<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2007/01/18/honor-code-exists-to-uphold-gospel-principles-create-environment/ |title= Honor Code Exists to Uphold Gospel Principles, Create Environment |first= Nicole |last= Miller |date= January 18, 2007 |newspaper= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref> Students may be brought to the attention of the Honor Code office by faculty, staff, or other students<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2006/05/26/universities-use-social-networks-to-find-misbehaving-students/ |title= Universities use social networks to find misbehaving students |first= Elizabeth |last= Stuart |date= May 26, 2006 |newspaper= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref> but "no anonymous reports will be acted upon".<ref name="Honor Code Faculty Information"/> BYU Events Staff patrol school dances for Honor Code violations.<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2006/01/17/byu-dances-keeping-it-clean/ |title= BYU Dances Keeping it Clean |first= Rosalie |last= Westenskow |date= January 17, 2006 |newspaper= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref> Cafeteria, library, athletics, and [[BYU Testing Center]] employees are asked to encourage students to follow dress and grooming standards, sometimes denying service to students not adhering to the code.<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2005/09/13/hbll-reviews-honor-code-enforcement/ |title= HBLL reviews Honor Code enforcement |first= Sara Elizabeth |last= Payne |date= September 13, 2005 |newspaper= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref> In 2001 it was reported that less than 2 or 3 percent of BYU students are referred to the Honor Code Office annually, though no percentage on punitive actions were given.<ref name="BYU Brass Suspend Two Gays"/> Data from 1955, however, showed that 9 students were expelled, 23 were suspended, and 72 were placed on probation.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilkinson|first1=Ernest|title=Seven Year Report of the President of BYU (1950 to 1957)|date=1957|publisher=BYU|location=BYU L. Tom Perry Special Collections UA 1000 Box 77|page=205|url=http://files.lib.byu.edu/ead/XML/UA1000.xml}}</ref>
===Beard Exemptions=== In regards to facial hair restrictions, permission to wear facial hair can be granted in three specific cases: For men with skin conditions aggravated by shaving, for theatrical performances, and (since a policy change in January 2015) for religious reasons.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Knox|first1=Annie|title=BYU clarifies beard policy; spells out exceptions|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/2057823-155/byu-clarifies-beard-policy-to-allow?fullpage=1|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=Salt Lake Tribune|date=14 Jan 2015}}</ref><ref name=wpbeard>{{citation | url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2015/01/14/brigham-young-university-adjusts-anti-beard-policies-amid-student-protests/ |title= Brigham Young University adjusts anti-beard policies amid student protests |first= Abby |last=Phillip |date= January 14, 2015 |newspaper= The Washington Post}}</ref> In regards to medical exemptions, students/faculty must visit a BYU Student Health Center doctor who will fax a recommendation to the Honor Code office. The student/faculty must then visit the office to fill out the requisite exemption paperwork. A new BYU ID card is issued including a symbol marked "BE" and a photograph with the facial hair. In regards to theater exemptions, students or faculty must obtain written permission from the theater or film company explaining the need for facial hair. Such exemptions are only granted for the duration of the production. Thus, in such cases a temporary exemption card issued. Religious exemptions will be coordinated through the university chaplain's office.<ref name=wpbeard />
===Ecclesiastical endorsement=== Students are required to sign in agreement to the Honor Code, Dress and Grooming Standards, Residential Living Guidelines, and Academic Honesty Policy yearly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ecclesiastical Endorsement Instructions for Students Attending BYU Provo |url=https://it.byu.edu/byu/sc_help.do?sysparm_document_key=kb_knowledge%2Cdf579dc52b967c047ed590a069da1557 |website=byu.edu |publisher=BYU |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150106175606/https://it.byu.edu/byu/sc_help.do?sysparm_document_key=kb_knowledge%2Cdf579dc52b967c047ed590a069da1557 |archivedate=2015-01-06 |df= }}</ref> Additionally they must have a yearly<ref>{{cite web|title=BYU OneStop|url=https://onestop.byu.edu/complete-ecclesiastical-endorsement|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU}}</ref> interview with a leader of their local religious congregation, or (for religious students or those without a local congregation) the non-denominational BYU chaplain and maintain this ecclesiastical endorsement<ref>{{cite web|title=Church Educational System|url=https://home.byu.edu/webapp/endorsements/|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU}}</ref> to attend BYU. In the past about 5% of BYU was not LDS,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Call|first1=Jeff|title=Religious freedom: What's BYU life like for non-LDS professors, students?|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/728999/Religious-freedom-Whats-BYU-life-like-for-non-LDS-professors-students.html|agency=Deseret News|date=21 Nov 1999}}</ref> but that number has shrunk closer to 1% in recent years.<ref>{{cite web|title=Religions represented at BYU, 2002-2014|url=http://typo.byu.edu/Article?id=97|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|access-date=2017-03-12|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170312201252/http://typo.byu.edu/Article?id=97|archive-date=2017-03-12|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Chommel-Bailey|first1=Lorraine|title=International, non-LDS students at BYU|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2015/10/14/outside-looking-in-international-non-lds-students-at-byu1/|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=14 Oct 2015}}</ref> The chaplain or religious leader is instructed to inquire about the student's and understanding of and adherence to specific policies. These include the ban on the consumption of specific substances, viewing pornography, any extramarital heterosexual "relations", any homosexual conduct, and adherence to the Honor Code, Dress and Grooming Standards, Residential Living Guidelines, and Academic Honesty Policy on and off campus. LDS bishops and branch presidents are additionally instructed to verify that LDS students demonstrate "appropriate and consistent church activity", "abid[e] by the standards of the Church", and are in "full fellowship".<ref>{{cite web|title=Ecclesiastical Endorsement Instructions for Church Leaders|url=https://it.byu.edu/byu/sc_help.do?sysparm_document_key=kb_knowledge,f6b1a65f2b1e70007ed590a069da1507|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU}}</ref> The chaplain or religious leader can revoke the endorsement at any time.<ref name="policy.byu.edu"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Rising BYU star thrown out|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/695250315/Rising-BYU-star-thrown-out.html?pg=all|agency=Deseret News|publisher=LDS Church|date=5 Feb 2008}}</ref>
===Honor code staff=== As of 2017, the enforcement of the BYU's Honor Code is directed by Spencer Hawkins,<ref>{{cite web|title=Department Directory|url=https://unicomm.byu.edu/directories/?sortParameter=H|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> who is under Vice Dean of Students Casey Peterson,<ref>{{cite web|title=Campus Life Organizational Chart|url=https://deanofstudents.byu.edu/content/campus-life-organizational-chart|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> who is under Dean of Students Vernon Heperi.<ref>{{cite web|title=Staff|url=https://deanofstudents.byu.edu/staff|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> Over the Office of Student Life is Vice President Janet S. Scharman,<ref>{{cite web|title=Department Directory|url=https://unicomm.byu.edu/directories/?page=3&sortParameter=S|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> who reports to university president [[Kevin J Worthen]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Prescott|first1=Marianne Holman|title=Kevin J Worthen installed as new president for BYU|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865610607/New-president-for-BYU.html|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=Deseret News|publisher=LDS Church|date=9 Sep 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Cecil O. Samuelson Retires; Kevin Worthen Becomes New BYU President|url=http://education.byu.edu/alumni/parents-and-grandparents/rediscover-byu/cecil-o-samuelson-retires|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> who is under the [[Church Educational System#Church Board of Education and Boards of Trustees|BYU Board of Trustees]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Church Educational System Administration|url=https://www.lds.org/church-education/about/ces-administration?lang=eng|website=lds.org|publisher=LDS Church|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Administration|url=http://catalog.byu.edu/about-byu/administration|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref> which is composed of [[General authority|general authorities]] and general officers of the LDS Church.<ref>{{cite web|title=BYU Administration|url=https://registrar.byu.edu/catalog/2013-2014ucat/AdminFaculty/Administration.php|website=byu.edu|publisher=BYU|accessdate=17 February 2017}}</ref>
===Housing accommodation=== Students have the option of living in on-campus housing, with family members who reside in the local area, or in off-campus housing which must pass a school inspection for health and safety, as well as satisfactory separation of gender quarters and compliance with other standards. Students under certain conditions can apply for a housing waiver for special approval.<ref>{{citation |url= http://och.byu.edu/contracted.html|title=BYU Contracted Housing|work=BYU Off Campus Housing|publisher=BYU}}</ref><ref>{{citation|url=http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/Housing.php|title=Off-Campus Housing|work=2009-2010 Undergraduate Catalog|publisher=BYU|access-date=2010-04-10|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120713061249/http://saas.byu.edu/catalog/2009-2010ucat/GeneralInfo/Housing.php|archive-date=2012-07-13|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *Single parents with children. *Single students living with parents. *Single students who are taking classes away from Provo. *Graduate students. *Under certain conditions, as determined by the Off-Campus Housing Office, the university housing requirement may be waived for other students who have a special circumstance or hardship. This approval is designed to ensure that students live in a safe environment that is consistent with the standards of the University. Since students are only allowed to live in BYU-approved housing, landlords in the area consider it important to meet the standard in order to gain residents. The housing standards mandate that bathrooms and bedrooms be off limits to those of the opposite sex. Members of the opposite sex are required to be out of the apartment by midnight.<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2006/06/12/honor-code-influence-helps-and-hampers-student-housing/ |title= Honor code influence helps and hampers student housing |first= Rebecca |last= Shippen |date= June 12, 2006 |journal= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref> Guns are permitted in off-campus housing only if the gun owner receives written permission from both the landlord and all residents in the apartment.<ref>{{citation |url= http://universe.byu.edu/2005/06/02/byu-housing-office-prohibits-firearms-in-apartments/ |title= BYU housing office prohibits firearms in apartments |first= Leaa |last= Forschler |date= June 2, 2005 |newspaper= The Universe |publisher= BYU }}</ref>
In 2003, BYU announced that beginning in 2007, housing would only be approved if it was within {{convert|2|mi}} of campus. The school did this out of concern that its Office of Residence Life was being stretched too thin and was unable to meet demands. Students feared the new boundaries might lead to a rise in apartment prices and decrease the amount of available housing. According to BYU, the effect would be minimal, as 98 percent of students already lived within the designated area. About 40 properties lost BYU approval due to the new guideline.<ref>{{citation |url=http://universe.byu.edu/2006/06/12/students-resistant-to-and-confused-by-new-housing-boundaries/ |title=Students resistant to and confused by new housing boundaries |first=Lesley |last=Larson |date=June 12, 2006 |newspaper=The Daily Universe |publisher=BYU}}</ref>
==Controversies== There has been several controversies surrounding BYU's honor code, with criticism from students, advocacy groups, local governmental institutions, and national press coverage.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
===YouTube Blocking=== As part of a BYU ban on websites containing sexual content, the popular website YouTube was blocked on all BYU networks. In 2007 [[Fox News]] highlighted BYU's blocking of pornographic and other sites, including [[YouTube]], from campus Internet connections,<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.foxnews.com/story/2007/02/17/brigham-young-university-bans-youtube-access-for-students/ |title= Brigham Young University Bans YouTube Access for Students |date= 2007-02-17 |publisher= Fox News |agency= [[Associated Press|AP]] }}</ref> pursuant to the code's prohibition of the viewing of pornographic material. BYU lifted the YouTube ban in 2009, again receiving nationwide press attention.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2009/06/27/brigham-young-university-_n_221908.html |title= Brigham Young University Lifts YouTube Ban |date= 27 June 2009 |work= Huffington Post }}</ref>

Expelled at BYU|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/03/31/lose-your-faith-get-expelled-at-byu.html|accessdate=17 February 2017|agency=The Daily Beast|date=31 March 2015}}</ref><ref name="ReferenceB">{{cite news|last1=Knox|first1=Annie|title=BYU graduates complain to accrediting board over school’s treatment of lapsed-Mormon students|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/2288397-155/byu-graduates-say-school-should-not?fullpage=1|agency=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=12 Mar 2017}}</ref> There are many non-believing and former Mormons on campus,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Andrews |first1=Emily |title=The Group: Utah County’s covert secular community |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110916155955/http://www.dailyutahchronicle.com/news/the-group-utah-countys-covet-secular-community/ |archivedate=2011-09-16 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=BYU Students|url=http://www.iamanexmormon.com/byu/|website=iamanexmormon.com|publisher=I Am An Exmoron}}</ref> and some have been expelled for publicly expressing disagreement or doubt.<ref name="ReferenceB"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Hollingshead|first1=Todd|title=BYU fires teacher over op-ed stance|url=http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/ci_3934360|agency=The Salt Lake Tribune|date=14 Jun 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Group of BYU grads says school shouldn’t expel ex-Mormon students|url=http://universe.byu.edu/2015/03/24/group-of-byu-grads-says-school-shouldnt-expel-ex-mormon-students/|agency=The Daily Universe|publisher=BYU|date=24 Mar 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Miet|first1=Hannah|title=When the Saints Go Marching Out|url=http://www.newsweek.com/2014/01/31/when-saints-go-marching-out-245158.html|agency=Newsweek|publisher=IBT Media|date=30 Jan 2014}}</ref> In 2014, the organization [[FreeBYU]] composed of BYU alumni and students asked the BYU Board of Trustees to reform the Honor Code to allow LDS students to change their religion,<ref>{{citation |url= http://www.freebyu.org/letter-to-byu/ |first= Caleb|last= Chamberlain |title= Letter to the BYU Board of Trustees |work= FreeBYU blog |publisher= 'FreeBYU' |accessdate= May 21, 2016 }}</ref> then subsequently challenged BYU's accreditation by the Northwest Commission on Colleges and Universities on the basis of the honor code's suppression of academic and religious ===Other universities=== In March 2008, the [[University of Texas at San Antonio]] was accused of plagiarizing a portion of BYU's honor code related to cheating and plagiarism.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/highereducation/entries/2008/03/31/utsan_antonio_honor_code_borro.html|title=The lowdown on higher education|work=statesman.com|first=Ralph K.M.|last=Haurwitz|date=March 31, 2008|publisher=[[Austin American-Statesman]]|accessdate=2014-04-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413164212/http://www.statesman.com/blogs/content/shared-gen/blogs/austin/highereducation/entries/2008/03/31/utsan_antonio_honor_code_borro.html/|archive-date=April 13, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.chron.com/news/article/UTSA-students-apparently-plagiarized-honor-code-1681070.php |title= UTSA students apparently plagiarized honor code |date= March 30, 2008 |newspaper= [[Houston Chronicle]] |agency= AP |accessdate= 2014-04-10 }}</ref> [[Southern Virginia University]], which also espouses LDS standards, uses a similar code of conduct.
===Student athletes=== The Honor Code received national attention in March 2011 when the university dismissed [[BYU Cougars men's basketball|BYU basketball]] player [[Brandon Davies]] from the team for violating the code,<ref>{{cite news |url= http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/columns/story?columnist=forde_pat&id=6175251 |title= BYU puts principle over performance |first= Pat |last= Forde |authorlink= Pat Forde |date= March 2, 2011 |publisher= [[ESPN]] |accessdate= 2014-04-10 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url= http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/03/03/no-3-byu-loses-after-dismissing-player-for-honor-code-violation/?hpt=T2 |title= No. 3 BYU loses after dismissing player for honor code violation |first= Jim |last= Kavanagh |date= March 3, 2011 |work= |publisher= [[CNN]] |accessdate= 2014-04-10 }}</ref> reportedly by having premarital sex,<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/cougars/51348870-88/davies-byu-code-honor.html.csp |title= BYU's Brandon Davies apologizes to teammates |first= Jay |last= Drew |date= March 2, 2011 |newspaper= [[Salt Lake Tribune]] |accessdate= 2014-04-10 }}</ref> the same day the college basketball rankings came out listing BYU as the #3 team in the nation. Davies was reinstated to the university the next school year, and returned to the basketball team, where he completed his athletic eligibility in [[2012–13 BYU Cougars men's basketball team|2013]].

===Facial hair=== {{Seealso|Beard#LDS Church}} BYU students led a campaign to loosen the [[Beard#LDS Church|beard restrictions]] in 2014,<ref>{{citation |first= Whitney |last= Evans |date= September 27, 2014 |title= Students rally for beard 'revolution' in Provo |url= http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865611874/Students-rally-for-beard-revolution-in-Provo.html?pg=all |newspaper= [[Deseret News]] }}</ref><ref>{{citation |first= Annie |last= Knox |date= September 26, 2014 |title= BYU student asks school to chop beard ban |url= http://www.sltrib.com/58458452-219/university-beards-beard-campus.html |newspaper= [[The Salt Lake Tribune]] |access-date= November 2, 2014 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20141125224803/http://www.sltrib.com/58458452-219/university-beards-beard-campus.html |archive-date= November 25, 2014 |dead-url= yes |df= mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{citation |first= Whitney |last= Evans |date= September 27, 2014 |title= Students protest BYU beard restriction |url= http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=31728643 |publisher= [[KSL-TV|KSL 5 News]] }}</ref><ref>{{citation |first= Annie |last= Cutler |date= September 26, 2014 |title= 'Bike for Beards' event part of BYU students' fight for facial hair freedom |url= http://fox13now.com/2014/09/26/bike-for-beards-event-part-of-byu-students-fight-for-facial-hair-freedom/ |publisher= [[KSTU|Fox 13 News (KSTU)]] }}</ref> but it had the opposite effect at Church Educational System schools: some students who had previously been granted beard exceptions were found no longer to qualify, and for a brief period the [[LDS Business College]] required students with a registered exception to wear a "beard badge", which was likened to a "[[badge of shame]]". Some students also join in with [[shame|shaming]] their fellow beard-wearing students, even those with registered exceptions.<ref>{{citation |first= Annie |last= Knox |date= November 24, 2014 |title= Beard ban at Mormon schools getting stricter, students say |url= http://www.sltrib.com/1867918-155/beard-ban-at-mormon-schools-getting |newspaper= [[The Salt Lake Tribune]] }}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=October 2015}}{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}}
'''[[Cram school]]s in Hong Kong''' (also commonly known as "tutorial schools") are commercial organisations that cater principally to students preparing for public examinations at secondary school level, namely the[[Hong Kong Diploma of Secondary Education| Diploma of Secondary Education]] (HKDSE), and its precursors prior to 2012, [[Hong Kong Advanced Level Examination|Advanced Level]] and [[Hong Kong Certificate of Education Examination|Certificate of Education]] (HKCEE) examinations.<ref name="scmp1893444" />
==Business model== [[File:KGE billboard.jpg|thumb|500px|"Star teachers" featured on a prominent billboard on [[Nathan Road]]]] Cram schools are relied upon by some primary school students and many secondary school students to endow them with techniques for public examinations in Hong Kong that determine students' acceptance to local universities.<ref name=scmp20090716/><ref name=scmp1893440/> According to the Census and Statistics Department of Hong Kong, a third of secondary school students went for private tutoring in the 2004–05 school year, spending a total of [[Hong Kong dollar|HK$]]18.9 million per month (2.42 million).<ref name="AP"> [https://www.usatoday.com/news/offbeat/2007-01-22-tutors_x.htm "Hong Kong tutors selling sex appeal"], [[Associated Press]], 20 January 2007</ref> On the lower estimate, the whole industry is worth more than HK$400 million,<ref name="Jiujik">[http://www.jiujik.com/jsarticle.php?lcid=HK.B5&artid=3000015690&arttype=MGT&artsection=CAREER 年薪千萬元的補習天王] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927215910/http://www.jiujik.com/jsarticle.php?lcid=HK.B5&artid=3000015690&arttype=MGT&artsection=CAREER |date=27 September 2007 }}, ''Jiujik'', 10 November 2006 {{zh icon}}</ref> and according to other reports, the industry is generating more than US$3.6 billion a year.<ref name="nyt">{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/01/business/global/01iht-cramside.html |title=In Hong Kong, Cram School Teachers' Image Rivals Pop Stars' |first=Yuk-hang |last=Ng |work=The New York Times |date= 1 June 2009}}</ref> Amongst these, [[Modern Education]] and Beacon College are the only listed operations.<ref name=scmp1893444/>
These establishments cater to the 478 thousand secondary school students in Hong Kong (2008 figures).<ref name=wealth/> The schools focus on the two major local public examinations, namely HKDSE and HKALE. Cram schools focus on teaching examination techniques as well as providing students tips on topics which may appear on the coming examination.<ref name=hk-magazine17682/><ref name=scmp20090716/> Monthly tuition fees per subject in 2009 were approximately HK$400 (US$51) for each student.<ref name=scmp20090716/> The fee for a course, such as English, can be HK$100 per hour.<ref name=wealth>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=36&art_id=90181&sid=25984870&con_type=3&d_str=20091106&sear_year=2009 |title=Wealth of knowledge |first=Nickkita |last=Lau |work=The Standard |date= 6 November 2009}}</ref> In 2015, fees were stable at around HK$500, due to tough competition amongst tuition centres and falling school rolls due to demographic factors.<ref name=scmp1893444/> The use of video tutorials, pioneered by Kevin Ko, has become a permanent feature in the industry in Hong Kong.<ref name=hks20091016/> Multimedia technology has permitted the leveraging of classes simultaneously to hundreds of students at two or more different locations.<ref name=scmp1893444/>
The Hong Kong Federation of Youth Groups surveyed 524 year five to year twelve pupils in 2012, 63 per cent of respondents said they were being tutored; approximately 56 per cent of those spent at least HK$1,000 a month on tuition fees.<ref name=scmp1893440>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education-community/article/1893440/hong-kongs-poor-children-lose-out-cramming-system|title=Rise of exam-cramming system will widen Hong Kong’s social divide, educators warn|date=19 December 2015|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref> The popularity of tutoring has been fuelled by aggressive social pressures and competition for university places for subjects such as medicine and law.<ref name=scmp1893440/>
=== Tutor profiles === Tutors are independent contractors to cram schools, who share their revenue with tutors. Tutors on the other hand bear their own overheads, such as advertising and promotion expenses; many hire assistants to research course materials and to answer students' queries.<ref name=scmp1893444/> The share of gross revenues paid to tutors may depend on their bargaining power (popularity), and whether classes are live or virtual. Media reported that the more successful amongst these are able to obtain a 60% share. Some liken themselves to stage performers, so cultivate their images and daily rehearse new content or delivery.<ref name=scmp1893444/> There are said to be approximately 20 such 'star tutors' in number within the industry in 2007, who made monthly gross revenues of HK$1 million or above.<ref name="AP"/><ref name="Sing Pao"/> Public disclosures made during the 2014/15 fiscal year by two leading cram schools indicated that Modern Education paid fees ranging from about HK$2 million to around HK$15 million to five tutors; Beacon College paid its top tutor HK$35 million in the same year, and another four tutors averaged approximately HK$4.8 million each.<ref name=scmp1893444/> By comparison, Hong Kong secondary school teachers earnings are capped at $68,915, and a primary school teacher was earning maximum $52,815 in 2009.<ref name=scmp20090716/> Some of the tutors, or "presenters", are model-turned.<ref name="AP"/><ref name="Sing Pao">[http://www.singpao.com/20060830/feature/870230.html 變質補習天皇 為錢走火入魔] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061125104853/http://singpao.com/20060830/feature/870230.html |date=25 November 2006 }}, ''[[Sing Pao]]'', 30 August 2006 {{zh icon}}</ref>
The schools apply a fandom approach to promote tutors, who dress fashionably and are given nicknames like "the Godfather of Science," "Brand-A tutor", "Super tutor" or the "Queen of English."<ref name="AP"/> They can be seen on billboards, full-page newspaper ads and TV screens in railway stations or on buses.<ref name="AP"/><ref name=scmp716876>http://www.scmp.com/article/716876/controversy-fails-take-shine-star-tutors</ref> Some of them have their own teams of stylists, fashion designers and photographers; many have personal web sites.<ref name="AP"/> Ken Ng, founder of Modern Education, claims credit for initiating this trend, and for "liberat[ing] the very feudal education system" whilst making a lot of money.<ref name=hk-magazine17682>http://hk-magazine.com/article/inside-hk/interviews/17682/ken-ng-king-cram-schools-and-celebrity-tutors</ref>
Unlike individual private tutors who advertise on sites such as adpost, kijiji and craiglist, cram schools regularly spend a lot on millions on front pages of papers, on the MTR and on buses. Multimedia techniques are increasingly deployed. To increase yield, once traditional classes are now supplemented by classes transmitted by video feed.<ref name=scmp20090716>Martin Wong, Yvonne Tsui, 'Star tutors' can net HK$1m a month, page C1, ''South China Morning Post'', 16 July 2009</ref> Since around 2004, tutors have produced promotional videos for posting to YouTube.<ref name=scmp1893444/>
In late 2015, media reported that Modern Education was overtly trying to poach a "star tutor" employed by a competitor. The tutor, likely to have been responsible for over 40 percent of the fees generated by rival Beacon College, was reported to have been offered a lucrative package representing an estimated HK$85 million (US$10.97 million) a year. The package included $30 million signing bonus plus 65% of all the revenue he generates throughout his 4-year contract period. Modern Education took out full-page advertising in two local journals to vaunt its offer publicly.<ref name=20151008ejinsight>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20151008-why-this-hong-kong-tutor-is-worth-22-barack-obamas/|title=Why this Hong Kong tutor is worth 22 Barack Obamas|work=EJ Insight}}</ref><ref name=20151009scmp>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education-community/article/1865497/want-earn-cool-hk85-million-hong-kong-tutorial|title=Want to earn a cool HK,5 million? Hong Kong tutorial school tries to poach top teacher from rival institution|date=9 October 2015|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref><ref name=hks45335927>http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=162018&sid=45335927&con_type=1</ref> Beacon College had revealed in its 2015 application for listing of the HK Stock Exchange that it made HK$236.4 million, HK$337.9 million, and HK$327.8 million in 2013, 2014 and 2015, respectively, and that its unnamed “top one tutor” was responsible for generating 43.6 percent, 45.5 percent and 40.5 percent of its turnover in those three years respectively.<ref name=20151008ejinsight/> The brazen attempt of Modern Education to poach the Chinese tutor signalled to investors the extent that these schools may be dependent on a single teacher.<ref name=20151009ejinsight>{{cite web|url=http://www.ejinsight.com/20151009-why-lam-yat-yan-is-walking-away-from-a-us10-mln-pay-day/|title=Why Lam Yat-yan is walking away from a US$10 mln pay day|work=EJ Insight}}</ref><ref name=hks45335927/>
==Criticism and controversies== [[Fernando Cheung]] , a member of the Legislative Council panel on education questioned the purpose of the money fuelling Hong Kong’s cram culture. Cheung said: “Our children are pushed into a system where they have to go through exercise after exercise, extracurricular activities, exam preparation and all that. Even when kids take up activities in arts and sports, they’re just there to be competitive and put one more thing on their resumes”.<ref>http://hk-magazine.com/article/inside-hk/hk-stories/17835/failing-grade-hong-kong-students-cant-stop-paying-cram-kings</ref>
In May 2008, the [[Independent Commission Against Corruption of Hong Kong]] stepped in to investigate allegations that HKCEE examination papers had been bought, and that K. Oten of [[Modern Education]] had sent out an analysis the current year's paper to examination candidates by text message during the exam. His employers immediately distanced themselves, saying he had been terminated.<ref name=probe>Carol Chung and Jeffrey Tam, [http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=65603&sid=18828288&con_type=3&d_str=20080508&sear_year=2008 "Tutor faces exam leak probe"], ''[[The Standard (Hong Kong)|The Standard]]'', 8 May 2008</ref> Oten had previously been dismissed by [[King's Glory Education Centre|King's Glory]] in April 2006 on several counts of violating his employment contract.<ref name=scmp20090716/> The court found him in breach, and ordered him to pay HK$8.87 million in damages to his former employers.<ref name=scmp20090226>Yvonne Tsui &Loretta Fong, Tutorial school sues star teacher for HK$10m, page C4, ''South China Morning Post'', 26 February 2009</ref>
For his satirical dramatisation of the tutoring sector entitled ''[[Trick or Cheat]]'' 《愛出貓》, Hong Kong director [[Oxide Pang]] was sued by one of the sector's biggest stars for libel. Kevin Ko, co-founder of Ever Learning, alleges the film was a libellous portrayal of him. The film's main character, named Seven Ko, uses all manner of unethical means, including bribery and having sex with an exams official to gain access to examination questions.<ref name=hks20091016>{{cite news |url= http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=11&art_id=89286&sid=25728499&con_type=1&d_str=20091016&sear_year=2009 |title=Top-earning celebrity tutor sues over movie |first=Nickkita |last=Lau |work=The Standard |date=16 October 2009 }} (note: Ko's name is misspelt 'Kelvin' in the Standard article - [http://kevinko.com see official website])</ref>
In 2002 and again in 2010, Chinese star tutor Siu Yuen became embroiled in controversies when his teaching manuals included essay answers that bore uncanny resemblances to the year end examinations. His teaching materials for written Chinese in 2010 included notes on how to write an essay on a cinema on fire, which turned out to closely resemble a written question the fifth form Chinese public exam the same year. Siu was accused of possessing insider knowledge.<ref name=scmp716876/>
== Notable cram schools in Hong Kong == According to the Education Bureau, there are almost 7,500 tutorial centres and branches across Hong Kong.<ref name=scmp1893444>{{cite web|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/education-community/article/1893444/hong-kongs-superstar-teachers-talk-about-their|title=Hong Kong’s rock star tutors: Meet the teachers earning more than the average British Premier League footballer|date=19 December 2015|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref> The ones with larger scale operations include: * [[King's Glory Education Centre]] (英皇教育) * [[Modern Education]] (現代教育) – 8 locations (2017)<ref name=wealth/> * [[Beacon College (Hong Kong)|Beacon College]] (遵理學校) – 16 locations (2017)<ref name=wealth/> * [[Ever Learning]] (活學教育) – 10 locations (2017)<ref name=thestandard20090929>{{cite news |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?pp_cat=30&art_id=88497&sid=25523495&con_type=3&d_str=20090929&sear_year=2009 |title=School mourns `Lai Sir' death in horror crash |first=Diana |last=Lee |author2=Wong, Adele |work=The Standard |date=29 September 2009}}</ref> <!-- This list is not meant to be exhaustive, and only includes significant players. Please include cites for new additions -->

{{redirect|Elitist}} {{refimprove|date=March 2011}} {{Discrimination sidebar|expanded=Social}}
'''Elitism''' is the belief or attitude that individuals who form an [[elite]] — a select group of people with a certain [[ancestry]], intrinsic [[quality (philosophy)|quality]], high [[intellect]], [[wealth]], special skills, or experience — are more likely to be constructive to society as a whole, and therefore deserve influence or authority greater than that of others. In the United States, the term ''elitism'' often refers to the concentration of power in the [[Northeast megalopolis|Northeast Corridor]] and on the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]], where the typical American elite resides – journalists, lawyers, doctors, high-level civil servants, businesspeople, university lecturers, entrepreneurs, and financial advisors in the [[quaternary sector of the economy|quaternary sector]], often in established technological or political catchments of their [[higher education]] [[alma mater]].{{citation needed|date=May 2018}}
Alternatively, the term ''elitism'' may be used to describe a situation in which power is concentrated in the hands of a limited number of people. Oppositions of elitism include [[anti-elitism]], [[egalitarianism]], [[populism]] and [[political theory]] of [[Pluralism (political theory)|pluralism]].
[[Elite theory]] is the sociological or political science analysis of elite influence in society: elite theorists regard pluralism as a utopian ideal. Elitism is closely related to [[social class]] and what [[sociologist]]s call [[social stratification]], which in the [[Anglo Saxon]] tradition have long been anchored in the "blue blood" claims of hereditary [[nobility]]. Members of the upper classes are sometimes known as the social elite. The term ''elitism'' is also sometimes used to denote situations in which a group of people claiming to possess high abilities or simply an [[in-group]] or [[En cadre|cadre]] grant themselves extra privileges at the expense of others. This form of elitism may be described as ''[[discrimination]]''.
==Characteristics== Attributes that identify an elite vary; personal achievement may not be essential. Elitist status ''can'' be based on personal achievement, such as degrees from top-rate universities or impressive internships and job offers, it can (in archaic societies) be based on lineage or passed-on fame from parents or grandparents. As a term, "elite" usually describes a person or group of people who are members of the uppermost class of society, and wealth can contribute to that class determination. Personal attributes commonly purported by elitist theorists to be characteristic of the elite include: rigorous study of, or great accomplishment within, a particular field; a long track record of competence in a demanding field; an extensive history of dedication and effort in service to a specific discipline (e.g., medicine or law) or a high degree of accomplishment, training or wisdom within a given field. Elitists tend to favor social systems such as [[meritocracy]], [[technocracy (bureaucratic)|technocracy]] and [[plutocracy]] as opposed to radical [[democracy]], political [[egalitarianism]] and [[populism]]. Elitists also believe only a few "shakers and movers" truly change society rather than society being changed by the majority of people who only vote and elect the elites into power. To elitists, the public is abjectly powerless and can be manipulated only by the top group of elites.<ref>{{cite web|title=Elite (elitist) theory|url=http://www.auburn.edu/~johnspm/gloss/elite_theory|website=auburn.edu|publisher=Auburn University|accessdate=13 August 2014}}</ref>
Some [[synonym]]s for "elite" might be "upper-class" or "[[aristocracy|aristocratic]]", indicating that the individual in question has a relatively large degree of control over a society's [[means of production]]. This includes those who gain this position due to socioeconomic means and not personal achievement. However, these terms are misleading when discussing elitism as a political theory, because they are often associated with negative "class" connotations and fail to appreciate a more unbiased exploration of the philosophy.
===Academic elitism=== {{anchor|Academic}} {{see also|Ivory tower}} {{unreferenced section|date=August 2014}} Elitism in the context of [[education]] is the practice of concentrating attention on or allocating funding to the best students, or those [[student]]s who rank highest in a particular field of endeavour. For example, a politician who promotes advanced classes for students deemed to be highly intelligent might be accused of elitism, even if this were argued to promote an egalitarian goal, such as curing disease. Elitism in education could be based on conventional assessment of learning ability, knowledge, or other abilities. However, an "elite" school can also mean a school for the wealthy or one that is hard to enter.
==Anti-elitism<!--'Antielitism' and 'Antielitism' redirect here-->== {{main|Populism|Pluralism (political theory)}} The term ''elitism'' and the [[pejorative]] title ''elitist'' are sometimes used by people who are not (or, who claim not to be) members of elite organizations. In politics, such terms are often used to disparage a politician's views as out of touch with the interests of the "[[average Joe]]". The implication is that the alleged elitist person or group thinks they are better than everyone else, and put themselves before others as a result. The definition of ''elitist'' is similar to that of the word "[[snob]]".
An elitist is not always seen as truly elite, but only privileged. The definition may have different appreciations depending on the political contexts. Since elitism may be viewed as something necessary for creating patterns of good intellectual or professional performance, it can be used also for maintaining conditions of lack of competition and privilege.
An early proponent of '''anti-elitism'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> was [[Georges Sorel]].<ref>Daniel Woodley, ''Fascism and Political Theory: Critical Perspectives on Fascist Ideology'', Routledge, 2010, p. 125.</ref>
===Egalitarianism=== {{further|Egalitarianism}} Elitism endorses the exclusion of large numbers of people from positions of privilege or power. Thus, many populists seek the (perceived, if not present in practice) social equality of egalitarianism, [[populism]], [[socialism]], or [[communism]]. They may also support [[affirmative action]], [[social security]], [[luxury tax]]es, and highly [[progressive tax]]es for the wealthiest members of society. All of these measures seek to reduce the difference of power between the elite and the ordinary. However, these measures to reduce difference could be seen as anti-[[meritocracy|meritocratic]] in that they avoid rewarding or promoting those who are the most competitive or provide the most effort in their endeavors.
The terms ''elitism'' and ''meritocracy'' are not equivalent in meaning. Professor Kenneth Paul Tan at the Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy asserts that "Meritocracy, in trying to 'isolate' merit by treating people with fundamentally unequal backgrounds as superficially the same, can be a practice that ignores and even conceals the real advantages and disadvantages that are unevenly distributed to different segments of an inherently unequal society, a practice that in fact perpetuates this fundamental inequality. In this way, those who are picked by meritocracy as having merit may already have enjoyed unfair advantages from the very beginning, ignored according to the principle of nondiscrimination."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tan|first1=Kenneth Paul|title=Meritocracy and Elitism in a Global City: Ideological Shifts in Singapore|journal=International Political Science Review|date=January 2008|volume=29|issue=7–27|pages=7|doi=10.1177/0192512107083445}}</ref>

{{Taoism}}
In [[Daoism]], '''The Five Precepts''' ({{zh|c=五戒|p=Wǔ Jiè|j=Ng<sup>5</sup> Gaai<sup>3</sup>}}) constitute the basic code of [[ethics]] undertaken mainly by lay practitioners. For monks and nuns, there are more advanced and stricter precepts. The Five Precepts are the same as the [[Five Precepts]] of [[Buddhism]]; however, there are minor differences to fit in with Chinese society.
According to ''The Ultra Supreme Elder Lord's Scripture of Precepts'', the five basic precepts are:
* The first precept: No Murdering; * The second precept: No Stealing; * The third precept: No Sexual Misconduct; * The fourth precept: No False Speech; * The fifth precept: No Taking of Intoxicants.
Their definitions can be found in an excerpt of ''The Ultra Supreme Elder Lord's Scripture of Precepts'': {{Quote|[[Daode Tianzun|The Elder Lord]] said: "The precept against killing is: All living beings, including all kinds of animals, and those as small as insects, worms, and so forth, are containers of the uncreated energy, thus one should not kill any of them."
The Elder Lord said: "The precept against stealing is: One should not take anything that he does not own and is not given to him, whether it belongs to someone or not."
The Elder Lord said: "The precept against sexual misconduct is: If a sexual conduct happens, but it is not with your married spouse, it is a Sexual Misconduct. As for a monk or nun, he or she should never marry or practice sexual intercourse with anyone."*
The Elder Lord said: "The precept against false speech is: If one did not witness what happened himself but telling something to others, or if one lies with knowing it's a lie, this constitutes False Speech."
The Elder Lord said: "The precept against taking of intoxicants is: One should not take any alcoholic drinks, unless he has to take some to cure his illness, to regale the guests with a feast, or to conduct religious ceremonies."**
The Elder Lord had said: "These five precepts are the fundamentals for keeping one's body in purity, and are the roots of the upholding of the holy teachings. For those virtuous men and virtuous women who enjoy the virtuous teachings, if they can accept and keep these precepts, and never violate any of them till the end of their lifetimes, they are recognized as those with pure faith, they will gain the Way to Tao, will gain the holy principles, and will forever achieve Tao -- the Reality."}}
<nowiki>*</nowiki>The precept against sexual misconduct also outlines that sexual acts such as premarital sexual conduct, adultery, prostitution, having intercourse with prostitutes, etc., are all sexual misconduct. (Original commentary: If the married spouses have intercourse too frequently, that is also considered sexual misconduct.)
<nowiki>*</nowiki>The term for married spouses ({{zh|c=夫婦}}) usually means "husband and wife"; the scripture itself does not explicitly mention [[homosexuality]]. (Original commentary: sexual misconduct is unfaithful sexual relationships [不貞為婬])
==See also== * Buddhist [[Five Precepts]] * [[Ten Precepts (Taoism)]]
